p: Fruits and vegetables are rich in water and nutrients, and, during storage, are ideal substrates for development of pathogenic microorganisms, such as Penicillium spp., Monilinia spp., and Botrytis spp. In addition to the resulting economic losses, some pathogenic postharvest fungi, such as Aspergillus spp. and Penicillium spp., represent a serious human health concern due to the toxins produced (ochratoxin A, patulin, citrinin, etc.) [ 4, 5]. Hence, the use of appropriate technologies is important to reduce losses, which increase during the maturation and storage of fruits [ 6].
